H0.text: The cell would continue with mitotic division if it is exposed to a chemical that inhibits the production of spindle fibers as it prepares for mitosis.

H1.text: The cell would undergo meiotic division if it is exposed to a chemical that inhibits the production of spindle fibers while it is preparing for mitosis.

H2.text: The cell would break open if it is exposed to a chemical that inhibits the production of spindle fibers while it is preparing for mitosis.

H3.text: The cell would not divide if it is exposed to a chemical that inhibits the production of spindle fibers while it is preparing for mitosis.

A4.text: Failure of this spindle assembly checkpoint can result in aneuploidy and may be involved in aging and the formation of cancer.

A5.text: The completion of spindle formation is a crucial transition point in the cell cycle called the spindle assembly checkpoint. If chromosomes are not properly attached to the mitotic spindle by the time of this checkpoint, the onset of anaphase will be delayed.

A6.text: A number of different species including H. sapiens, D. melanogaster and C. elegans require the central spindle in order to efficiently undergo cytokinesis
